title: Boris Johnson ‘pauses’ Brexit bill after MPs vote against accelerated timetable
text:
The Brexit deal was passed earlier this evening (Picture: Getty Images)

MPs have voted against an accelerated timetable which would see the Withdrawal Agreement Bill concluded in under three days.

The programme motion was rejected by 322 votes to 308, creating a majority of just 18.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has now told the Commons he will be pressing ‘pause’ on the bill, despite MPs voting in favour of it just minutes before.

However, he stated that he would continue to discuss with EU leaders whether they will grant an extension or not.

Boris started his address by saying it was ‘joyful’ that the Commons had ‘actually accepted its responsibilities together, come together, and embraced a deal’.

He has now ‘pressed pause’ on the bill (Picture: Getty Images)

However, he continued: ‘Let me be clear. Our policy remains that we should not delay, that we should leave the EU on October 31 and that is what I will say to the EU and I will report back to the House.

‘One way or another we will leave the EU with this deal, to which this House has just given its assent. I thank members across the House for that hard-won agreement.’

He did not mention a general election in his address, despite threatening to call one before Christmas earlier today.

The 110-page Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which also contains an additional 125 pages of additional notes, was read in the Commons for the first time last night.

Labour had already stated before this evening that the programme motion did not allow enough time for ‘sufficient scrutiny’ of the deal’s legal text.

Jeremy Corbyn told the Commons that Boris had been the ‘author of his own misfortune’ (Picture: PA)

It was defeated by a majority of 18 (Picture: Parliamentlive.tv)

Their sentiments were then quickly followed by the DUP, who also said they could not back the intensive timetable.

Tonight Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told the Commons that Boris had been the ‘author of his own misfortune’.

Making the Prime Minister an offer, he continued: ‘Work with us, all of us to agree a reasonable timetable, and I suspect this House will vote to debate, scrutinise and, I hope, commend the detail of this bill.

‘That would be the sensible way forward, and that is the offer I make on behalf of the opposition tonight.’

Father of the House Ken Clarke told the Prime Minister he didn’t see the logic in pausing the bill and asked him to reconsider.

However, he recommended that the government come back with just a modest adjustment to the timetable proposed, as ‘three to four days would certainly do it’.
